qas.question: What major conflict is Myanmar known for?

answers.text: one of the world's longest-running ongoing civil wars.

qas.question: What portion of the government was eventually separated from government participation?
What type of government is now established in Myanmar?
Are previous leaders a hendrence to the current government?

answers.text: former military leaders still wield enormous power in the country

qas.question: Has the country been able to overcome the problems of government with the previous regime?

answers.text: Aung San Suu Kyi's party won a majority in both houses, ending military rule.

context: For most of its independent years, the country has been engrossed in rampant ethnic strife and Burma's myriad ethnic groups have been involved in <a0_0>one of the world's longest-running ongoing civil wars.<a0_0/> During this time, the United Nations and several other organisations have reported consistent and systematic human rights violations in the country. In 2011, <a1_0>the military junta<a1_0/> was officially dissolved following a 2010 general election, and <a2_0>a nominally civilian government<a2_0/> was installed. While <a3_0>former military leaders still wield enormous power in the country<a3_0/>, Burmese Military have taken steps toward relinquishing control of the government. This, along with the release of Aung San Suu Kyi and political prisoners, has improved the country's human rights record and foreign relations, and has led to the easing of trade and other economic sanctions. There is, however, continuing criticism of the government's treatment of the Muslim Rohingya minority and its poor response to the religious clashes. In the landmark 2015 election, <a4_0>Aung San Suu Kyi's party won a majority in both houses, ending military rule.
